instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S4: What is 3V3_S4? This is an abbreviation of PP3V3_S4, a 3.3v power rail when the machine is in an S4 state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Keyboard/Trackpad/Bluetooth/WIFI
threads.message: I havenn't had this one before. Functioning board otherwise. It's liquid-damage but I can see no corrosion in any way. I'm having trouble finding the USB chip that controls all of this (or at least TP/KB/BT.) Does anyone know which chip it is on this model? I've scoured the schematic back and forth and am not seeing that central chip like the <CHIP>U2700</CHIP> on the older <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boards.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Keyboard/Trackpad/Bluetooth/WIFI
threads.message: Wifi is PCI-E, BT is USB and trackpad is SPI. The common thing between them is I think <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Keyboard/Trackpad/Bluetooth/WIFI
threads.message: [FONT=Arial]Awesome, thanks, I wasn't going to get to that answer too quickly on my own. I had no idea this board could boot up and work seemingly fine (other than theses issues) without <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>. It was at about 2V. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> trace was blown up at <RESISTOR>R8115</RESISTOR>. I ran <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> across the board from <RESISTOR>R1460</RESISTOR> and everything's working great now. Thanks again.[/FONT]
